transcript:
Patient: The cognitive experiment was really eye-opening for me. I decided to test the belief that "I should always put others' needs before my own." I realized that this belief was causing me a lot of stress and leading me to neglect my own self-care.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Jamie. Can you tell me more about how you tested this belief and what you learned from the experiment?

Patient: Well, I decided to prioritize my own needs for a day and see what happened. I turned down a request from a friend to help them move because I had planned to spend the day hiking and reconnecting with nature. At first, I felt guilty for saying no, but as the day went on, I realized that taking care of myself made me feel more energized and positive. I was able to be more present and supportive in my interactions with others because I had taken time to recharge.

Therapist: That's a wonderful example of how challenging a "should" can lead to positive outcomes. By prioritizing your own needs, you were able to show up more fully for others in the long run. This experiment also highlights the connection between our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. The belief that you should always put others first led to feelings of guilt and stress, which in turn influenced your behavior of neglecting your own needs.

Patient: Exactly! It's like a vicious cycle. But breaking that cycle feels scary and uncomfortable at times.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel that way, Jamie. Challenging long-held beliefs can be uncomfortable because it requires us to step outside of our comfort zone. But as you've seen, doing so can lead to positive changes and personal growth. Remember, discomfort is often a sign of progress, not a reason to stop moving forward.

Patient: That's a good point. I guess I need to keep reminding myself that it's okay to prioritize my own needs and that doing so doesn't make me selfish or a bad person.

Therapist: Absolutely! And that's where the positive data log can be helpful. By keeping track of the times when prioritizing your needs leads to positive outcomes, you can start to build evidence against the belief that you should always put others first. Over time, this can help you develop a more balanced and compassionate view of yourself and your needs.

Patient: I like that idea. I think I'll start adding those experiences to my positive data log and refer back to them when I'm struggling with feelings of guilt or selfishness.

Therapist: That's a great plan, Jamie. And remember, challenging these beliefs is an ongoing process. There will be times when you slip back into old patterns of thinking, and that's okay. The important thing is to keep practicing and reminding yourself of the progress you've made.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That's really encouraging to hear. I feel like I'm starting to develop a better understanding of how my thoughts and beliefs are impacting my emotions and behaviors.

Therapist: You're doing an excellent job, Jamie. As we continue to work together, you'll become more skilled at recognizing and challenging these patterns. And eventually, you'll be able to apply these skills independently, even after our sessions have ended.

Patient: That's my goal – to become my own therapist and have the tools to manage my depression on my own.

Therapist: And I have no doubt that you'll get there, Jamie. You've already made significant progress, and I'm confident that you'll continue to build on that progress in the coming weeks and months.
